awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms of Triple Energy Transfer and Polaron Formation in Nanocrystals
awd_abstract_narration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program in the Chemistry Division supports Professor Tianquan Lian and his group at Emory University to study energy transfer process and excited state lifetimes of nanomaterial systems critical to efficient and cost-effective solar energy conversion.  This research is aimed at advancing two specific types of energy conversion technologies based on quantum dots (small semiconductor crystals). The first technology is photon upconversion.  This process refers to converting two low energy packets of light (photons) into a higher energy photon, such as converting invisible infrared light to visible light.   The second technology is the use of nanocrystals made from a specific category of materials called perovskites often used in solar cells. Unlike traditional solar cells, perovskite nanocrystals offer the possibility of tuning or adjusting the solar cell properties. This research may provide important guidance on the design and improvement of the energy conversion devices.  Educational and broaden participation activities include the development of a new course on renewable energy and a demonstration module for the Atlanta Science Fair. 

With this award from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program, Professor Lian’ group carries out the research with three specific aims.  The first aim is to test the theoretical models of triplet energy transfer from quantum dots to molecular acceptors by examining its dependence on the electronic coupling strength and driving force using lead halide perovskite and cadmium chalcogenide quantum dots of different size and shell thickness.  The second aim is to investigate the effect of exciton fine structure on triplet energy transfer rates from nanocrystals to molecular acceptors by examining their temperature dependence and to control these rates by changing the exciton fine structure through nanocrystal shapes.  The third aim is to study the property of polarons (formation mechanism, size and energy) in low dimensional lead halide perovskite crystals, examining their dependences on the size, nanocrystal dimensionality, cations and solvent/ligand environment. The findings of this study can advance the understanding of triplet energy transfer from quantum dots to molecular acceptors and polaron formation in low dimensional perovskite nanocrystals. These advances, in turn, provide important guidance on the design and improvement of the energy conversion devices that are based on the abovementioned materials and processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Mechanisms of Triple Energy Transfer and Polaron Formation in Nanocrystals

Project outcome

    In this project, Prof. Tianquan Lian and a team of graduate and undergraduate students at Emory University studied the mechanisms of triplet energy transfer from quantum confined nanocrystals to molecular acceptors and polaron formation in low dimensional perovskite nanocrystals. Photon upconversion is a process that can upconvert two low energy photons into a high energy photon through triplet-triplet annihilation. It has found promising applications in bioimaging and photodynamic therapy and as a potential approach to overcome the Shockley-Queisser limit in solar cells and photocatalysis. Triplet energy transfer from quantum dots to molecular acceptor is a key efficiency limiting step in many upconversion schemes. We completed a series of study of the mechanism of triplet energy transfer (TET) from QDs to molecular acceptors, in which we showed that 1) trap state in quantum dots can mediate TET to molecular acceptors, 2) QD surface ligand plays an important role in determining the pathways of TET from QDs to adsorbed acceptors, both direct and indirect pathways can operate, depending on the ligand length, 3) triplet energy transfer can occur from both the QD dark and bright exciton states, 4) TET rate to acceptor decrease exponentially with the shell thickness in CdSe/CdS core/shell QDs. We also demonstrated that Lead Halide Perovskite (LHP) Nanocrystals can photocatalyze atom transfer radical polymerization(p-ATRP). 2D LHP NPLs are promising materials for blue light emitting thanks to the strong quantum confinement. We reported the important effects carrier trapping on charge separation and recombination in these materials. Finally, the optoelectronic properties of quantum confined semiconductor NCs depend critically on the band edge electron, hole and exciton fine structures, which can be probed by transient absorption (TA).  To advance the understanding of the VB hole state filling effect, examined how an exciton and a single carrier (electron or hole) block the excitonic transition in cadmium chalcogenide quantum dots and NPLs and provides insights into the nature of single hole states in nanocrystals.
The research findings have deepened the understanding of exciton fine structure in NCs, mechanisms of QD-sensitized TET, effects of trap states on charge separation in NCs, and mechanisms of QD-sensitized atom transfer radical polymerization reactions. These findings provided design guidelines for many potential applications of low-D NCs, including photovoltaics, photocatalysis, photon-upconversion, bioimaging and photodynamic therapy. The PI and his team have actively participated in various outreach programs and provided educational and research opportunities for undergraduate students through programs such as the Scholarly Inquiry and Research Experience (SIRE) and Summer Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE). These grants contributed to the training of three undergraduate students and two of them have successfully co-authored papers. In addition, our senior PhD student has involved in both the Initiative to Maximize Student Development (IMSD) and National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBOCChE) to assist in recruiting more students of color and mentoring the current underrepresented students in the chemistry department. The team has also hosted lab tours for middle school students to introduce them to research and created a game called the band gap dodgeball race to illustrate exciton formation in differing sizes of quantum dots. The grant support has led to over13 published papers and contributed to the training of 8 PhD students and 3 undergraduate students. In addition, these results have been broadly disseminated through presentations in departmental seminars and national and international meetings.


Last Modified: 04/30/2024
Modified by: Tianquan Lian
